ï»¿Date Me Doc: Steven Elleman
Feel free to send questions, feedback, snark, love letters, etc to steven.elleman@gmail.com . 


The intent of this doc is to put some basic facts about myself online. If these facts feel aligned, then reach out. Some folks have reached out to say this kind of doc â€œspoils the mysteryâ€. To me, the mystery is our emergent dynamic. It is what uniquely arises from us, what dance we co-create. 


The previous version of this doc was aggressively autistic, feel free to check it out if you like walls of text: Date Me Doc: Steven Elleman (old)
About Me 
I worked as a professional software engineer for 7 years, I quit last year to try to align my main life threads into one coherent braid. There are three threads in my life: (1) communal living, (2) secular religious exploration, and (3) â€œDWebâ€. 


(1) matters to me because thereâ€™s magic to communal living that has made my life so much richer, and I want family in a communal context. (2) is about my relationship with myself and relationship with others. The magic that (1) offers feels like the right environment for (2), and Iâ€™ve been exploring different secular religious communities and running experimental retreats. (3) is a technical movement about a bottom-up version of the Internet and our digital world. I think (1) is the right vehicle for (3). Communal living is all about navigating shared resources and infrastructure; adding home servers into the mix makes a lot of sense. 


What unifies these threads is simple: home. If I had a home with a community of people I deeply admire and love I think thatâ€™d satisfy most of my needs. Iâ€™m interested in building a new kind of home from the bottom up, one that makes sense to me. This is both the simplest and grandest kind of endeavor, creating my own community-home is a constant act of world-building. I long for a partner-lover-friend who wants to build it with me.
Romantic Dynamic 
I build intimacy slowly. Using the body as a metaphor, I build intimacy through head -> gut -> heart -> sex. Head: on an intellectual level I need to think we have aligned values and goals. Gut: I need to feel safe with you, that youâ€™re a stable, reliable, and integrous person. Only after my head and gut feel safe do my internal inhibitions drop, and I feel permissioned to fall in love. And only after that do I feel permissioned to feel sexual attraction. My story for this order and degree of inhibition is that I fear being trapped in a partnership similar to my parents â€“ if Iâ€™m going to be committed I need to feel deeply aligned. Typically the way I build intimacy is through shared projects and lots of talking or writing. Romantically so far my pattern has been heterosexual and serially monogamous, and I would like to be a father.


Ideologically I subscribe to â€œrelational presenceâ€; I believe relationships of all kinds should honor whatever is present and alive, over stories of the relationship. What does a shared commitment to presence and aliveness look like? When stories are prioritized, feelings can be repressed out of a sense of responsibility or obligation. This is putting the cart before the horse. Itâ€™s putting intellectual stories over feelings which often represent a deeper and more embodied truth. In rational positivist thinking, the intellect trumps subjectivity and feelings. I believe this perceived superiority is at the root of many contemporary problems; it amounts to gaslighting. Feelings are facts. If feelings are facts, theyâ€™re always valid and legitimate. All wants, desires, fears, aversions, boundaries, etc are first-class citizens; stories must follow from the feelings, the cart must follow the horse. This allows radical honesty and transparency, eliminates unhealthy shame and repression, and ensures stories are constantly brought back into alignment with whatâ€™s actually being felt, whatâ€™s actually present and alive.


The stories we tell often feel rooted in a desire for safety and control, fear of loss can prevent relationships from changing in necessary and beautiful ways. I see possession in conventional monogamous relationships as an attempt to prevent change and loss; in the process it puts the cart before the horse, it can put the story of the relationship before appreciation of whatâ€™s real. Loss is inevitable. People change. Weâ€™re going to die. I want to feel safe in the impermanence and change. Beyond acceptance of loss is savoring the preciousness of life. Denial of impermanence prevents savoring, it leads to clinging to stories and grasping for control that simply doesnâ€™t exist. It leads to attachment to a story or image of self and partner over who they actually are, and in the process, aliveness is stifled, and self-deception takes over. 


I want to see and know you as you are, and I want to be seen and known in turn. I want to honor you in your full aliveness, and even if itâ€™s brief and fleeting, at least itâ€™ll be real. 


This belief has been shifting all my relationships pretty significantly over the last year, and Iâ€™m still seeing how it coalesces with my historical romantic dynamic. 
Romantic Archetypes 
There appear to be recurring archetypes that Iâ€™m drawn to. â€œAutisticâ€ â€“ women who emphasize intellect, principles, analytical reasoning â€“ I feel safe with this archetype and thereâ€™s a shared interest in systems and reasoning. â€œPost-Rock Bottomâ€ â€“ women who had to go through emotional turbulence and have hit rock bottom before â€“ I admire the resilience and acceptance of this archetype, often it has emotional depth and contrast, which I love. I often like being a â€œgroundâ€ for my partner and seem to be attracted to depressive and bipolar women â€“ I like being a source of hope, optimism, care. â€œShamanicâ€ â€“ I often like women who marry a high degree of sensitivity, attunement and intuition with spirituality. â€œFieryâ€ â€“ I want a warrior. I like strong women. Beneath my outer layers of personality is a lot of fire. Iâ€™ve noticed I like women who are fierce, I know I can handle them, and I want them to be able to handle me. I can like the â€œBratâ€ archetype â€“ I like being of service, but I like taking control in other contexts â€“ some brattiness can strike a nice balance.  


If youâ€™re some combination of Fiery Post-Rock Bottom Shamanic Autist Brat please reach out!

profileDetails.fullText:
Here's looking at me â€“ Telegraph
Here's looking at me
Luca
May 17, 2024
Here's looking at me
Luca
I am a run-of-the-mill carbon-based life form, living on the planet currently known as Earth (or so I've been told). If you're reading this, it's highly likely you've come across my profile on Hinge. This must be the fourth or fifth time I've created an account there. It's not that I haven't had any luck -- I've connected with some interesting people, but obviously nothing that has worked out well enough to stop me wanting to go back.
I thought I'd write a profile (a "
date-me doc
" of sorts) for those piqued enough by the very limited window provided by Hinge to want to get to know me more, but on second thoughts I thought I'd do something different. So here's a list of reasons NOT to date me:
I'm married. No two ways about it: some time in 2005, I entered into a civil marriage, which is still valid on paper. The marriage didn't work out, and my wife and I have lived separately since 2018. Neither of us see the point in getting a divorce as of now, but this will obviously change if there's a good enough reason for it. Needless to say, neither of us has problems with the other seeking other romantic interests.
Steinbeck once referred to poor Americans seeing themselves as "temporarily embarrassed millionaires". Well in my case the pandemic and its aftermath has found me in a similar circumstance of temporary embarrassment (which I hope is truly temporary). I work with languages and have freelanced all my working life -- something that worked just fine, despite the unavoidable ups and downs, until a few years ago. Every now and then, it does begin to look like things might pick up again, but only time will tell if they really do. So all you prospective sugar babies can happily walk right past me and I hope you manage to find your pot(belly) of gold. But for those of you who might still be willing to overlook this: I have never been that interested in making money or other indicators of worldly success. Right now, the only interest I still have in doing so is to uphold my commitment to my children (did I mention I have children? Well I do: two of the most wonderful persons I've ever had the pleasure of knowing).
I can be a bit of a curmudgeon -- it's hard to get me excited about what's happening in the world outside (or even convincing me of its existence on some days), at least not for its own worth. In the right company, however, even the most humdrum, everyday activities take on the aura of the most exciting thing the world has ever known, and more than anything else, this quest of mine is for that right company.
That's it for now, but I'm sure there are many more reasons to weigh the prospect of seeing and going out (or staying in) with me very carefully. I promise to add them to the list as and when they occur to me.

Sandra Bemâ€™s androgyny framework is the actual beeâ€™s knees.  Hereâ€™s the rundown:


There are culturally tagged â€œmasculineâ€ and â€œfeminineâ€ modalities of thought, feeling, and behavior.
A fully developed human has mindfully cultivated both in themself through a combination of deliberate self-work and acquiring varied life experiences.
That human is the Avatar of shitty gender constructs, bending all the elements at once:
competence and warmth, yin and yang, nurturance and agency, assertiveness and receptivityâ€¦
According to Dr. Bem, they've risen to the rank of â€œandrogynousâ€, the peak of human potential.


Dr. Bem came up with this idea and developed research tools to measure people on a two-axis system of â€œfemininityâ€ and â€œmasculinityâ€, with the really cool people landing in the upper-right quadrant, high on both scales.  Those folks can display â€œsituational appropriatenessâ€ across a wide variety of contexts, either by switching modes or by blending both modes at once.


Bemâ€™s androgyny feels like a cousin to two of my other favorite ideas in philosophy, which are the golden mean (watching out for â€œtoo muchâ€ and â€œtoo littleâ€ in literally all things) and Hegelian dialectics (thesis/antithesis/synthesis).


So, am I masculine?  Thatâ€™s a very solid â€œyes-andâ€.


During the final minutes of an attempt at a sub-5:30 mile, I prayed to the departed ghost of my Marine grandfather for the strength to endure and exceed my body's limitsâ€”and I clocked in at 5:24, shaking, on the verge of heaving, but triumphant.  I'm excellent with technical systems.  I achieved the competitive rank of Onyx in Halo 5.  For projects that really matter (and some that don't), I plan carefully using numbers and spreadsheets.  I lift weights.  The old Teddy Roosevelt quote stirs my heart and lights a fire in me.  I like making my loved one feel safe and protected and provided-for (so long as I'm not over-parentified by my peer).


Iâ€™ve also cried unabashedly at the songs in Steven Universe, which I purchased season-by-season in its entirety.  The lyrics of â€œLove Like Youâ€â€”if you know, you know.  Visually, I'm obsessed with color.  I want to be aesthetically beautiful and to create beauty around me.  I'm captivated by sensations and will visibly surrender to joy when I look out over the hills, snuggle up under a soft blanket, or take the first bite of a good meal.  As I mentioned earlier, my special interest (other than deck-builders and approximately every subject in nonfiction) is relationships and feelings.  I'm a cat whisperer and absolutely melt for kitties, baby talk and all.  And I want someone to kiss me like this:


  

If you spend time on the parts of Reddit where this
sort of image gets posted, please send me a message.


I could be an appropriate partner for (among other sorts) a cishet AFAB who is herself holistically developed, and honors and craves the same breadth and depth in her male partner.  Historically, most of my partners have been bi+ and neurodivergent, so the gender thing took a back seat to a grounded notion of compatibility and like-mindedness.  In any case, if you like what you see, I would be glad to hear from you.  Just understand that policing my â€œmasculinityâ€ would be grounds to end the relationship.


All of this has bearing on family life!
Catch me teaching grit, agency, and excellence to my future kids, hopefully by modeling these myself.
Also catch me spoiling those kiddos with bottomless emotional attention, attunement, and co-regulationâ€”which I expect to model just as much in my relationship with my spouse.


I greatly value some kind of bend toward Bemâ€™s androgyny in others.
In AMABs, that usually looks like culturally conspicuous EQ and warmth (with their agency and excellence taken for granted by society).
In AFABs, it usually looks like culturally conspicuous agency and excellence (with their EQ and warmth taken for granted by society).


  

Can we please teach this to all preschoolers, regardless of sex?


One more hot take:


Iâ€™ve developed a view that temperament and neurotype really are what gender is cracked up to be.  People empirically differ in their essential, embodied naturesâ€”meaning blank slatism is falseâ€”but the pink/blue bucket system is a stain on our culture.  Temperament and neurotype show uncountable natural variations, giving rise to â€œendless forms most beautiful and strangeâ€ among individuals.  People are best bucketed by their contextually relevant distinctions (I call them â€œCoRDsâ€), which vary completely from one context to the next.  Reproductive sex class is almost never a CoRD, unless we're actually talking about intercourse or family planning!


The truth about a personâ€™s talents, instincts, and proclivities dwells in that person, and the optimally developed version of that person is bespoke and exists independently of cultural archetypes.  I don't know, nor do I expect ever to know, what traits statistically correlate with reproductive sex class at a population level in a truly culture-fair society.  I do know that if you're dealing with (for example) a young Norah Vincent, who, as an AFAB child in the early 1970's, persisted doggedly in wearing jeans and climbing trees despite every imaginable social pressure to the contrary, then you love and embrace that lilâ€™ lesbian tomboy from the bottom of your heart.  And for goodness's sake, can we please make heroes rather than martyrs of our highly sensitive AMAB children?


What this means for parenting is: Iâ€™m going to let my kids show me what their natural talents and interests are, and then Iâ€™m going to nurture those without too much editorializing.  (Yes, rooting out bias and subtle influences is a hard problem, but still.)


  

The user selects negative-one genders, and the fortress bursts into flames.
Case study: BayHouseWarming
In 2021, as I was moving from Seattle back to the Bay Area, I tried founding a group house with 4â€“6 ambitious residents from among my friend group.  I affectionately called this project the Bay House.


My vision was to gather folks who would positively peer-pressure each other to achieve their dreams more proactively, in a warm and nurturing environment where we all enjoyed one another, shared meals, kept up with each other's lives, and did activities together.  (Looking back three years later, I recognize this as a variation of â€œfamilyâ€, which I now call one of my core values.)


I shot for the moon and landed in the treetops: I succeeded in establishing the house with a total of 3 residents, plus a fourth who visited for a time.


I took on sole responsibility for furnishing our new nestâ€”everything from budgeting to design to logistics.  When one housemate's parents came to see the place, they pulled me aside and said, â€œYou put all this together?  This is not some bachelor-pad setup.  This is a grown-up house,â€ nodding with a raised brow.  That's still one of my favorite compliments I've ever received.


I decided to plan and host a housewarming party, hoping to knit together different parts of my friend group and establish the house as a social venue.  Naturally, I named the party â€œBayHouseWarmingâ€.


I still have the planning sheet in my personal archives:


  

Is this â€œmasculineâ€ or â€œfeminineâ€?  You tell me.


The unchecked items got done in time; I just never went back to check the checkboxes.  By then, the list had served its purpose.


I also made this document to help track food prep.  It's an early example of what I now call [pun redacted]â€”my personal survival tool for C.W.N. (cooking while neurodivergent).


Here's the rest of the story in photos:


  

The appetizers turned out delicious.
(The cans are all soft drinks, most with low sugar.
I'm a lifelong teetotaler; all my parties are dry.)


  

I make frequent efforts to share my love of hot sauce.


  

Ready for trouble.


  

Make it double.  (Or sextuple.)


  

Nametags, just as the sheet foretold!


  

The crew's all here.  The whiteboard mounted over the hearth was lots of funâ€”
every time a visitor came over, something new would appear on it.
We got poems, lewd drawings, people's hopes and dreams, more lewd drawingsâ€¦


  

A chessboard is to some of my friends as a paper bag is to cats.


  

During the chess match, one of the spectators started
drawing the other guests on paper plates.  I have no
idea where the palette came from.


  

Main course: vegan chili and cornbread.
I'm a â€œreducetarianâ€ myself, and it's always easier to plan
meals for large groups by defaulting to a vegan menu.


  

It was the kind of dinner you'd want to eat outside.


  

This is why.  The view from the back deck that evening.


  

As intended, the party set the stage for many afternoons of four-squareâ€¦


  

â€¦with the good ol' crewâ€¦


  

â€¦plus many evenings of Telestrationsâ€¦


  

	  

	  

	â€¦which got pretty wild.


Below is the Telestrations booklet responsible for those reactions.
William (far left above) saw only page 4, then drew page 5, and was VERY pleased with my guess on page 6.
  

	  

	  

	  

	  

	  

	

	  

	

	

Sex and other wonderful things
Is it bad form to talk about sex in a dating doc?


â€¦No.


â€¦Maybe?


Let's settle for a middle ground.  Here are some books I've read attentively:


* Magnificent Sex: Lessons from Extraordinary Lovers by Peggy J. Kleinplatz and A. Dana MÃ©nard
   * (HIGHLY recommend!)
* Come As You Are by Emily Nagoski
* She Comes First by Ian Kerner
* Rethinking Sex by Christine Emba


I'll save most of my steamy shares for a later time.  Here's just one for now:
I have a strong track record of creating a reverse orgasm gap in my relationships.


If you're my sweetie, I will learn all the ways you like to be touched, both in and out of bed.  ðŸ˜˜
I care a lot about this!  In a fully selfish sense, I come alive by making you come alive.  Thereâ€™s nothing better than a partner's joy.
On good terms with my ex
At 23, I met and fell in love with a very charming human, who is now working on her own dating doc, which will get a solid endorsement from me.  [UPDATE: Here it is.]
That relationship continued for about eight years.  We lived together for four of those years, then moved apart.
Finally, we decided that we had irreconcilable differences and it wouldn't make sense for us to marry.  Our paths have disentangled somewhat, and weâ€™re currently in a cooling-off period of low contact, but this person is still like family to me and to my relatives.
Expect her to continue playing a role in my life!  Sheâ€™ll likely appear at family gatherings in the future.  Itâ€™s possible sheâ€™ll be â€œAuntie Aliciaâ€ to my kids.
How I'm searching
Using dateme.directory, I ran a database query for every F and NB doc worldwide.  (My data cutoff was 2024-04-14.)  Then I carefully read all 130 of them, skipping one.  That part took a total of 10 hours.  I built a spreadsheet as I went, recording my feelings about each doc on a dual 7-point scaleâ€”separately measuring the strength of my positive response and the strength of my negative response.  Both scales work like this:


7â€”overwhelmingly present
6â€”clearly present
5â€”weakly present
4â€”ambivalent or unclear
3â€”weakly absent
2â€”clearly absent
1â€”overwhelmingly absent


I recorded my data in normalized form so I could write relational queries.
Then I wrote a query to generate a bubble chart visualizing the frequencies of different score pairs:


  

When I look at the size of the 5/6, 6/6, and 7/6 bubbles,
a certain Taylor Swift song starts playing in my head.


I also wrote a query to grab the data records forming the lower-right portion of the chart (high positive scores, low negative scores) and sort them in a certain way.  That tells me which docs to revisit at length.


From there, intuition takes the wheel.


If you get an outreach message from me, know that a lot of forethought and appreciation went into it, and I've been spending lots of quality time with your writing!  ðŸ˜Š
Contact info
If anything in this doc has inspired you to say hello, pen a spicy response, ask me out on a date, or just be my pal, you're warmly invited to do either of the following:


* Text me at two zero six, two two five, seven zero four two
* Email me at: langhisc at [DELETE THIS] gmail [DELETE THIS] dot com


If you try one method and you don't get a response, please try the other.  As long as this doc is published and visible, I'll try to acknowledge every message I receive.


Thank you for making it this far!  Have a blessed rest of your existence, dear reader.  âœ¨

Iâ€™m a co-founder of Impact Academy - a non-profit that runs ambitious educational programs to enable young people to use their careers to solve some of the most pressing problems and contribute to a better future. I also work as a coach for impact-driven people. I enjoy communal living and have lived in multiple group houses -  including one with a six-month-old baby, but am also open to other forms of communal living.
Before that, I did a bunch of different things throughout my life. I trained as a medical doctor, did biosecurity research at Stanford that might have contributed a tiny bit to the prevention of pandemics, co-founded Effective Altruism Denmark, co-authored a book during my undergrad, and created a course for 1000+ students.
Iâ€™m also a mediocre salsa dancer and a non-terrible singer (who loves to sing Alicia Keys songs). On the more adventurous side, I've spent four months in Nepal and hitchhiked from Copenhagen to Budapest.
My journey
Due to luck and a great teacher, I had a wake-up call when I was 16 and I realized that I was on a bad trajectory. I started to work on forming my values, character, and lifestyle to take care of myself and lead a more meaningful and altruistic life (such as supporting refugees). As I was deciding on my degree, I considered many different options (from social science to philosophy) as Iâ€™m very curious (and still am! ðŸ™‚). However, I narrowed it down to medicine and psychology and eventually decided on medicine as I thought it was the most promising way of understanding the human condition and thus help others the most. Especially those who needed it the most. This was mainly driven by altruism, curiosity, and unnoticed guilt.
During the first years of my undergrad, I co-authored aÂ bookÂ with a Norwegian author who had inspired me when I was younger. The book we wrote together was on how to study effectively and I was later hired to create and teach a course for all medical students at my university. I eventually decided to pivot away from this because I believed effective altruism and global health were more important (not an easy decision!). I had several existential crises and almost dropped out to join Effective Giving when it was starting out. However, I decided to finish the degree and build the EA community in Denmark (which I did for three years next to med school). During these later years, I also started finding â€œmy people,â€ with whom I built deep friendships that last to this day, frequently bringing me joy and gratitude.
Towards the end of med school, I ran a career experiment in biosecurity at Stanford University, SSI, and the US CDC for two years. My research was on mortality monitoring usingÂ EuroMOMOÂ because I predicted itâ€™d be useful in pandemics (pre-covid). This included living in an incredible group house with entrepreneurs in Palo Alto and trying coaching. These experiences introduced me more seriously to entrepreneurship and coaching - both of which Iâ€™ve been pursuing since 2020. In 2022, I had the fortune of meeting some awesome and like-minded people who had a similar vision so we co-founded Impact Academy.

[l]This is harder than it sounds, and has proven more difficult than anticipated. Which might be my problem right there, that I had expectations for not having expectations ðŸ˜
[m]Except of course when messing around and ambiguity is the joke. Ambiguity is a great joke.
[n]The term is described far more fully in this blog article, which provides additional good foundational understanding of a relationship.
https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/02/pick-life-partner-part-2.html
[o]Sure Iâ€™ve stayed briefly in the mountains and such, but that doesn't provide me an understanding of what living in the country would actually be like. It's like suggesting I move to LothlÃ³rien; it doesn't make sense to me.
[p]After he retired he became the head of the bay area chapter of the Auduban Society! Dude is a walking library of birds. Ask him about a call and he can give you the bird's full name and description from the sound alone.
[q]It was after surgery in the summer of 2020, so not leaving my room was a responsible choice, not (just) a lazy one.
[r]Even Marie Kondo conceded this point after her third child. Life creates chaos, and sometimes that chaos is better to manage than eliminate.
[s]I learned this by currently living in a house with a rambunctious puppy. Send help.
[t]Good choice, by the way!

a date-me-doc, yay!
is this a date-me-doc?!
Ã¼h-hm.
(means 'yep' with a kind of 'insightful' undertone)
Here I come,
in case there is someone out there silly enough to be strong enough to be my man
ðŸ»â€â„ï¸
(apparently, this means polar bear in some dialects...)
Hallo, hallo. This is K speaking.
(I'll tell you my name later, of course. Even my shoe size. Just not sure how this 'going public with loads of seriously personal' works yet...)
I'd like to start with some controversies, if I may - they should tickle your interest buds, all being well.
And there you go, the first one has just
landed
, and even without intent!
I make up phrases in English sometimes, quite probably because it is my second language. But aren't your interest buds all the merrier now that they know they exist?!
For illustration
(
though, a non-linguistic one
):
photographic evidence of the moment when my nephew and I invented the 'simultaneous reverse swing selfie' 10 years ago.
(I've made the whole sorcery into a 12" video but this site wouldn't... so this is the end frame, as you can tell from the catharsis on our faces.)
alrighty then, on with the controversies...
I love hiking
but hate camping
these two loonies
I wasn't supposed to befriend because
I am allergic to dogs
but I've walked them for a friend with the greatest joy dozens of times
best sound and smell!
aaand I am allergic to dust ðŸ˜©
I'm creative (in some ways)
and while you might not get the sense instantly, I'll have you know that I've just done an online test and it says it is one of my signature strengths, OK?!
time to get back to the allergies...
I love dogs, horses and cats are OK, too, but if you have any of these living in your house, we'd be in a pickle...
But hey, don't write me down as 'the allergy girl'! I might be lactose intolerant and vegetarian, too, but no hayfever can sweep me off my feet!
Jokes aside (hope you've been having the time of your life so far), I'm a heterosexual female, 178 cm tall and 60 kg, give or take, and an atheist. I turned 40 three months ago, which feels so recent, but if you think about it, that's one Q already... ðŸ˜¶
I live in London normally (but presently unemployed so sticking it out in a cheaper place) but if a job offer took me to Copenhagen, Stockholm or Amsterdam by any chance, I wouldn't weep my eyes out. (I love bikes and definitely prefer cycling to public transport... but not just for the bike culture, of course!)
I work in project management in the creative industries but I've just completed a short course in environmental sustainability and oh my, there's just so much potential in so many areas of sustainable development! I firmly believe that if anything, technology and science will save humanity from exterminating this planet but there's so much everyone can do! I hope you agree with that and don't let climate despair get the better of you!
I hate waste in any of its forms (materials, time, money, energy....). I wish I had the skills of a chemical engineer to invent more ways to upcycle/recycle waste. Or the powers of a social psychologist to ignite a grassroots movement that would turn overconsumption into something society would end up frowning upon and would eventually lead to global behavioural change... (My folks call me naive at least once a fortnight so it's OK if you think I'm a bit too far into wishful thinking, don't worry.)
Lacking the skills of scientists, though, at least I have a skeleton idea of a dark comedy tv show (in terms of flavour, think of a layered cake of Boat Story, Back to Life, After Life, and, me, of course) that would stick it into the faces of local governments (and the main one) re how much more they could actually do (or try to do) to solve/ease a bunch of social and environmental issues at local levels. We'd be following the stumblings of a 40-something main character who is completely lost on the tracks of self-development (but sane, just kind of driftwood-ish a bit), and circumstances make him/her settle into a small town community, and we watch in awe how these stumblings sometimes turn into brilliant solutions to problems without the main character's slightest awareness of his/her role in them... anyway, I could go on but you'd need to sign an NDA. However, if you have any ties to Two Brothers Pictures or Harry Williams or Jack Williams (the two brothers) or their EAs or their PAs or their postman, get in touch this instant, of course! (Ricky Gervais' management agency I had tried already, the most junior of their junior staff bounced me off in a blink of an eye, albeit, politely ðŸ™‚ )
But yeah, if not changing the perception of the population about overconsumption and overproduction, there are still a billion things to try, right?! I did some decluttering a couple of months ago, took crates of items to a market with the intent of donating the proceeds to animal shelters. Luckily, I managed to sell a dozen items or so. Then winter came, the books got soaked right after unpacking one time so I took the whole thing online. I created a website, photographed hundreds of clothes, books, utensils, knick-knacks, and spent ages uploading and describing everything and getting word out on local social media... then 3 books and a cheesegrater got bought. But hey, the intent was there!
Dreaming of having a small abode right by a lake
This spot is my favourite so far but I'm happy to go for an old Scandinavian villa on sale for peanuts with you, to do up while I can swim a lot and make lots of hot beverages for us. Or a Mediterranean little house? With colder drinks?
Are you also scanning social media channels like cheappropertyeurope and such daily? (Ours will have solar panels and a heat pump and all the clever things, OK?)
I asked a friend to describe me as this seems to be a frequent advice re dating profiles... so this is from her (and I am all blushing while typing):
A clever introvert with such integrity but little confidence.
She values tranquility over fanfare but she is all in for adventures and creating memorable experiences.
Keeps lots of her ideas to herself despite being a creative person, possibly due to being afraid (that lack of confidence thing...).
Intelligent, great sense of humour, quick on the uptake but a bit sceptical first about new things. Sometimes it takes a bit of letting guards down but after that she is a truly loyal, trustworthy friend, by your side through thick and thin.
She is monogamous and would go for problem-solving without hesitation rather than throwing it all in way too soon. She expects honesty and loyalty in return as well: once trust is gone, it would be a rocky road winning it back.
The person who will fall for her (who will seriously want to make her happy) will get a most devoted wingman (woman), that's for sure. And the two of them will carry around laughing their heads off, probably. She is such fun when there's no need for walls.
There. Can you believe all that praise?!
Embarrassingly
lovely, isn't she? But she has known me since I was about 3 years old so... ðŸ˜¬
And you know me a little by now, too, don"t you? - let's get pragmatic and avoid wasting each other's time (if that's the case) because wasting is so insanely stupid.
I guess this aversion to waste accounts for my thriftiness and indecisiveness. For me it takes longer to decide on a purchase or an action plan than for most people - and if you are the kind of clever guy I'm after, it might have already clicked for you that what I'm trying to do with the best intentions is just another form of wasting, i.e. wasting time under the illusion that I'm working out the optimal usage of resources.... ðŸ™ƒÂ  how dumb, huh?! If you'd found me out, get in touch by all means. I could definitely welcome someone in my life who catches me out when I should be. And the best would be if you were patient and easy-going, too. Or just patient.
I don't seem to be attracted to men with long hair and I am not keen on facial hair, either (I have a theory that circa 98.7% of men sporting a beard or a moustache would look incomparably more handsome without them. There's such a tiny segment of the male population who might actually benefit from growing facial hair that I could almost elevate this theory into a general rule. But I won't, cause I respect the rights of those 1,214 men to attractiveness.).
I prefer not being taller, stronger, faster, fitter or heavier than my man.
I'm not planning on having kids so it would be great if you didn't have/want any, either.
I guess I am just writing this whole novella because I wonder if there's a chance after you have already lived half of your life to find someone who can add kindness and smiles to the remaining years while you want to add the same to theirs because you both understand how precious companionship actually is. Just looking for a team mate (whom I quite fancy), I reckon.
You don't need to be a dashing prince with wealth or have a great sense of style but as long as your sense of humour is ace and you like to fool around while also being aware that no relationship can get far without respect or honesty and that maintenance on it will most probably be needed along the way, too, we could be in for something.
Be old enough to know that you carry the responsibility for all you do and say but young enough to still want to venture out there and enjoy tomfoolery. (38-46 would cover that, you think?)
birthday present
loved it! (I mean, I didn't get the plane...)
good to become friends
with strangers who bring your food
didn't get this aircraft, either
but maaan, holding out your phone on a trike for a photo when there's absolutely nothing underneath is a thrill!
a full body shot
is probably also expected... Serious face was art director's doing. Location global fashion giant's choice.

What my friends say about me
â€œLawrence is pretty emotionally mature and insightful in a bunch of ways, and is happy to talk about feelings. [..] I think he might be the best person I know for helping people get over lack of intellectual self-confidence and problems with being intimidated by technical content. [..] He holds himself to very high standards, in a way that can sometimes hurt him but is also often very positive â€“ heâ€™s extremely receptive to feedback and is very non-defensive even when heâ€™s upset. I think heâ€™d be a good match for someone who wants their relationship to be a big source of growth and improvement, but also of security and unconditional affection.â€

â€“ Nat Kozak
More about me 
I often feel intense emotions. I sometimes stop while walking or driving to just take in the view and reflect on how good things are. I get excited about clever ideas and am deeply touched by acts of kindness. I feel on a deep level that most people are very good and are trying their best, and it makes me really sad when they fail or have a rough time. I feel very upset when people are unreasonable, and I often feel a strong desire to fix problems I see around me.

Other Pictures

________________
Appendix
Some things I believe about dating docs and dating:
Dating docs arenâ€™t (just) for finding dates. I think a significant fraction of the value of dating docs comes from the process of writing; another large fraction comes from communicating information with future partners that might not come up naturally in the first few dates. Iâ€™m also not super convinced that dating docs work well for finding new people to date, compared to e.g. asking people out in person. So this doc errs on the side of being more informative as opposed to promotional. 


Emotional and social intelligence are real and important. There are many skills in actually making relationships work, both in terms of knowing yourself and in terms of knowing how to relate to others. While I can be a fan of numbers and spreadsheets, itâ€™s important to be in touch with who you are and what you want, and also who your partner is and what they want. Also, communication is important! 


Shared interests are significantly less important than shared values and shared desire to make a relationship work. I think dating apps and docs tend to focus too much on screening for shared interests or experiences, which I think can easily be developed over time. (In particular, Iâ€™m happy to pick up your interests! In the past Iâ€™ve picked up the interests of previous partners.) On the other hand, deeply held values are probably unlikely to change, and I donâ€™t think romantic relationships work without both parties wanting it to work and putting in the effort.


Most disagreements and issues can be worked through (given shared values and a desire to make the relationship work). I think I have a lot of growth mindset for relationships; I think that many common points of disagreement can be worked on. For example, I think that issues like division of labor (for chores) or different hobbies can generally be solved if both people are willing to try. As a corollary, I think that fights are really bad in romantic relationships; the whole point is to be on the same side, and work toward a mutual goal. Accordingly, Iâ€™ve had very few fights in my past romantic relationships. 


Security is necessary for people to grow in relationships. I personally value relationships that push me to grow and do better, but I donâ€™t think these relationships can be stable without a firm bedrock of security and mutual trust. After all, itâ€™s pretty hard to be ambitious if you feel like a single misstep could cause your partner to leave you.


Relationships can be thought of as trade agreements, but you generally shouldnâ€™t. Relationships are trade agreements (in the sense that every persistent interaction can be thought of as a trade agreement), and this frame can be somewhat helpful. For example, it highlights the fact that relationships should be a positive sum voluntary endeavor, and that both partners should try to provide things that are to their comparative advantage. However, I find that this framing can often cause people to take an adversarial stance toward their partners (i.e. a trade negotiation), or cause people to value tangible, concrete things about their partners over emotional support or vibes, and so donâ€™t think that people should think about relationships this way by default. 


Additional writing samples:
I guess the largest repository my public writing is my LessWrong account: https://www.lesswrong.com/users/lawrencec

* Love languages that currently come easiest: quality time, acts of service
* Mix of intro- and extroverted? Medium-sized social battery? I like meeting new people occasionally, and love hosting or hanging with friends. But after e.g. a fun weekend of full-time social exposure, I need a day or two of quiet to recup. I lean heavily toward quality over quantity of friendships.
* I think Iâ€™d like to have children one day, but I have lots of uncertainty here.
* Currently in Boston but pretty flexible: could move to basically any major city in US or EU. Preference for East or West Coast of US, France or UK.
* Fluent in English and French (would love it if you are too!)
* Current work: AI policy researcher, screenwriter.
* B.A. and M.A. in Philosophy
* Vegetarian when Iâ€™m ordering, flexitarian otherwise. (Would struggle to live as a vegan: cheese is a strong part of my identity. Could be swayed.)
* Not religious
* Non-smoker, glass of wine on occasions
How to proceed:
If you think youâ€™d like to meet, or chat with, feel free to reach out at ctroutcsi@gmail.com, or here on messenger, or text me at 781 518 8996! (I think messenger or text are more reliable, since emails will sometimes go to spamâ€¦) If youâ€™d like to learn more about my work/hobbies, feel free to visit www.ctrout.art.


I know it can be intimidating to reach out, but of course I made this doc to meet new people, so donâ€™t be shy :)

Honestly my Twitter probably tells you more about me than this does: @WillowChem
Hi! I'm Anna Crow/Anna Magpie, haven't settled on that yet, a 23-year-old trans woman living in the United Kingdom.
As of writing this (1:17am BST, September 5th 2024) I am in the process of attempting to independently fundraise my salary so I can go to Stanford and run a longitudinal study monitoring tens of thousands of different biomarkers on people beginning, then throughout gender affirming hormone therapy, in order to begin to develop a foundational understanding of how to coordinate complex signaling pathways in real world biological systems.
I am
currently applying to computational biology PhDs mostly in/around London. My core interest is in understanding biology â€œacross scalesâ€. How do we integrate molecular biology data into a coherent whole in order to make useful predictions about disease, with a particular focus on aging. A subquestion I find particularly interesting is the extent to which regulatory networks are defined by complex, non-linear interactions vs simple additive ones. This question has big implications for combination therapies and, more generally, how fast we should expect biomedicine to progress.
M
y life is a little up in the air at the moment, I'm currently staying at CEEALAR, but hopefully moving to London sooner rather than later.
Polyamorous by default. I want to have one or two people that I'm extremely special to, and as long as I feel special to someone I can't bring myself to care about whether they're having sex/romance with other people; monogamous relationships just sound like too much work.
Chronic infodumper, if we date, you can expect rambles on things like
Biology, especially cellular biology, the mechanisms of aging, and mathematical models of evolution. Evolution is a better engineer than you are and I will tell you exactly why
Military history, I have a particular interest in the development of early semi-automatic firearms, and how this was influenced by institutional thinking around infantry doctrine. However I'm a modern warfare geek in full generality. Also I have strong opinions about people with strong opinions about the F-35.
Aquaculture and ornamental fish. Iâ€™m a keen tropical fishkeeper, although I haven't been able to pursue this seriously lately due to the housing constraints associated with being a student.
If you also like these topics, that's great, but if not I'm probably happy to listen to you if you ramble as well.
Generally eclectic, very into HEMA (Historical fencing with an emphasis on the martial art), bouldering, hanging out in places which have neat people to talk to (hackerspaces, etc.), and photography, almost exclusively wildlife, but someday I'll get into astro (even if you don't do that part with me, it would be great if you accompanied me on the outdoor walks. You will learn about birds and you will enjoy it). I also like to read: Trying desperately to get out of the rationalist monoculture, so have picked up â€œAn experiment in criticism by CS Lewisâ€ and in the middle of â€œThe guns of Augustâ€
I have extremely strong feelings about moral responsibility and individual virtue, especially as they relate to interpersonal relationships. In general I think that the biggest distinction between me and others isnâ€™t intelligence or aptitude, I just care more. I also value serious, precise thinking and try to be fairly ruthless about avoiding what I can best term â€œvibes based analysisâ€ alongside discouraging it in others. Iâ€™ve deliberately cultivated an instinctual uneasiness about hard to falsify claims. I want to date someone who helps me to be a better thinker, a better truthseeker. Stress test my claims, point out when I'm being more of a soldier than a scout and judge me for it, etc.
My ideal partner would be someone kind, extroverted and intelligent, who likes when I ramble and can ramble back at me, and enjoys cuddling me and having me occasionally draped over their arm. You should be an independent thinker who tries to avoid uncritically reciting Â recieved opinions. Ambitious or at least interested in improving yourself to a similar degree that I am, and willing to help me as I start assembling the life I want outside of university.
The tone of this document is possibly a little stand-offish, that's just my writing style. I am an extroverted, 6â€™5â€ trans woman with motor coordination issues; this makes me an inherently ridiculous person. I
can't
take myself too seriously. â€œBouncyâ€ probably captures my default orientation in most social settings. Again, go scroll through here for a much better sense of my demeanor

Summary
I am a disaster.


Iâ€™m an assistant professor working on Bayesian social and formal epistemology, the philosophy of AI, and the foundations of physics. Somehow I have ended up with two PhDs, one in particle physics, and one in the philosophy of science. I am something of a polymath. My ErdÅ‘s number is less than or equal to four.






I am kind, thoughtful and curious. I am excited by, and open to new ideas. I strongly value openness and honesty. I am shy, introverted and almost certainly terribly socially awkward. I am a neurodivergent trainwreck. I am often found at the epicentre of a whirling void of chaos, but this is just by coincidence. Imagine a confused and profusely apologetic teacher running in late to teach their class, and dropping their books everywhere.


I am vegan, somewhere on the (highly heterodox) left politically, feminist, and very loosely adjacent to (or aligned with?) effective altruism and rationalism.


I am (very) British. Sorry about that.


It is very important to realise that I am definitely not â€œfunâ€. Don't even *think* about trying to take me on an â€œadventureâ€.
Interests
My interests are rather eclectic. I particularly enjoy discovering new, elegant and holistic ideas that simplify and unify a great many threads: this applies not just in physics, but in every field of human knowledge. A selective summary of some things I often think about might include:


* Physics â€“ especially quantum field theory and particle physics. 
* Philosophy â€“ my specialisms are in formal and social epistemology and the philosophy of science, but letâ€™s face it, every area of philosophy is almost definitionally interesting.
* Rationality and Bayesianism.
* Cognitive science and artificial intelligence â€“ obviously.
* Why isnâ€™t my code compiling?
* Politics/economics/sociology. 
* History.
* Music and music theory.


Again, please let me stress this list is non-exhaustive. I am generally very fascinated by other topics as well.


I wonder at the nature of time, space and the cosmos. I marvel at the mysteries of human history and the patterns exhibited in human societies, minds, biological structures and other complex systems, deconstructing and analysing the various media of human culture. I am particularly fascinated by the problems of epistemology, and other areas of philosophy. How should we interpret quantum field theories? Is it possible that the Universe is deterministic? What does it mean for A to cause B, and does that imply a direction in time? What makes time so different from the dimensions of space? When are two scientific theories equivalent? Is scientific knowledge cumulative? How can we justify the use of Occam's razor in induction? How important is the "look elsewhere effect"? Why does anything exist at all? How strong is the anthropic principle? Is a high level of artificial intelligence imminent and what are its implications for society and the economy? Should we aspire to have a society without work? Is it OK to have incommensurable moral values? How culturally contingent is the modern, Western ideal of liberty? Is it possible to improve human happiness or are we stuck on a hedonic treadmill? Also, how can we save the political left in Western Europe in a time of globalisation, secular stagnation, and a resurgent China? Is the Eurozone doomed? How can we save the Labour party from itself? A question possibly more intractable than anything else posed here! When I am out and about, I often think about urban design, public spaces, and architecture too. Or I mull over post-Soviet hauntology. I particularly enjoy discovering new, elegant and holistic ideas that simplify and unify a great many threads: this applies not just in physics, but in every field of human knowledge. There are, I think, few forms of happiness greater than the satisfaction that arises from the creative application of thought to a problem and discovering a brilliant solution. I love being introduced to new ideas, so if you think you know something that would interest me, please do share it!

In some ways, I might take this too far: I instinctively veer away from groupthink, tribalism or veneration/idolization, in a way that probably can make me seem disagreeable. I seem unusually disinclined to naturally align my opinions or attitudes towards those of other people around me.


I sprinkle a lot of what I say with very subtle and dry humour, which very few people understand or notice. From this, you should probably conclude that I'm actually not very funny.


I am very open to new ideas, and generally curious. I am very much a high-decoupling thinker, although I see the value of being able to think in a low-decoupling way too. I do enjoy exploring ideas in a way that can sometimes come across as unintentionally controversial or provocative. I can comfortably suppress this, but I think I get on best with people who also enjoy thinking in this way.

I like integrity, authenticity, and the calm search for enlightenment. I dislike extravagance, gaudiness, and unjustified grandiosity.

However, occasionally I can overthink things, in a way to ensure I do not inadvertently pressure or harm other people. 


I am very ambitious and motivated. People tend to perceive me as something of a workaholic; however, this is only the case with work I passionately enjoy, or am very stressed about. I am a terrible procrastinator at everything else, especially anything involving admin. I can be very strong-willed on certain things; unfortunately motivating myself to do things I find tedious is not one of them. Some people find that I can be very stubborn; like some non-Newtonian fluids, my rigidity can increase under pressure.
Psychology
Sometimes I feel like the fated star-child, but then the camera dolly-zooms, and in a dizzying gestalt shift I realise that I am actually a barely-functional human being. It bemuses me that some people find this profile intimidating, because in truth I am usually a chaotic mess, stumbling from one fiasco to another.


Clearly, I am â€œneurodivergentâ€. I think I am autistic (self-diagnosed), I have ADHD (sort-of diagnosed) and I am dyspraxic (actually diagnosed!). The possibility that I might have ADHD only occurred a few years ago (I had a complete misconception of what this was); since then I have been taking vyvanse/elvanse (lisdexamfetamine), which has improved my life incredibly. The only comparable experience I can think of is when I first put on glasses. 


As a result of all this, I am mostly a scatter-brained, highly forgetful disaster. I am naturally fairly incompetent at most basic day-to-day tasks. I do my best, but my best is usually pretty terrible.


Anyway, I probably havenâ€™t mentioned this yet, but I am also highly forgetful.


In terms of many types of social interactions, I am pretty spectacularly awkward. I am usually better one-on-one than in groups, but I generally prefer large groups to small groups (more opportunities to hide). I am very introverted, by which I mean I tend to find social interaction very exhausting. This decreases when I grow more comfortable with someone, but usually it is still somewhat tiring. However, I actually really love exploring getting to know interesting people, and I generally do enjoy and value social interaction. Iâ€™m just able to do much less of it than some people, and need a lot of time to myself.


For whatever reason, I think I am actually very good at intuitively understanding and emotionally reading people. This is something that I have never found difficult. However, there are probably some social conventions that I miss or donâ€™t understand. That being said, I donâ€™t think my understanding is all that bad: there are some advantages to viewing things as an outsider, a sort of alien anthropologist. (But of course, I might not know what I donâ€™t know!)


I have high levels of anxiety overall. This is very much lower than it used to be, but is probably higher than average. I had OCD as a teenager, and still have some mild OCD tendencies (yes, I am mildly triggered by the poor alignment of the images at the top of this profile). In the past, I have experienced some mental health problems including depression. In recent years, Iâ€™ve been remarkably happy and mentally healthy.


Over the last seven or eight years, I have felt increasingly more alive, and reinvigorated. A lot of my mental health problems have become less severe in one way or another. I have gradually been learning to fall back in love with myself. This has been an extremely romantic process.
Physicality
Physically speaking, you could describe me as an organic, self-organising, irreversible, dynamic, non-linear, open, dissipative system, far from thermal equilibrium.


Thatâ€™s not what you were looking for? Fine, fine, if you really insist, here are some more â€œsalientâ€ features. I am:


* 34 years old
* Anatomically male
* British (obviously)
* Average height (around 175cm, or 5 feet, 9 inches tall)
* Average weight (with a bmi around 23 at the time of writing)
* Presumably not unfit (I am a fast walker, and I run 6 days a week)
* In no way "in shape", unless the shape you have in mind is some sort of blobitectural abomination (perhaps a GÃ¶mbÃ¶c?)
* Physically healthy (except for very mild asthma)
* White/caucasian.


I have:
* Green-brown eyes
* Disaster hair
* Glasses due to being short-sighted.


You can probably infer my approximate appearance from the pictures, some of which were even taken within the last decade.


Relationship Things
I am genuinely (yes, genuinely) open to forming many kinds of new connections, or just seeing how things evolve. That could include forming friendships, relationships, or other things. However, I would prefer to meet people without strong expectations or assumptions about a relationship escalator.


I quite like the polyamory model, and my prior experience with it has generally been successful.  I would be open to various relationship models ranging from monogamy to relationship anarchy, with the right person or people. I see pros and cons of different models. Overall, this is something I am more pragmatic about than ideological, and in general I am fairly flexible. One partner said (perhaps accurately) that I was too much of a relationship anarchist to ever identify as one.


N.B. I do have some ongoing entanglements, so I may not be compatible with very strict forms of monogamy. I am open to looser forms of monogamy.


However, regardless of the particular model, I try to form relationships on as rational a basis as possible, allowing a particular arrangement to develop naturally between individuals. I very much tend to view each friendship/relationship on its own terms, which means that they often don't fit easily into socially-established categories. Genuine communication is essential. Again, I take openness and honesty as very fundamental prerequisites for being able to interact with other people in the most positive possible way.


I tend to dislike â€œnew relationship energyâ€, and donâ€™t experience this as strongly as some people seem to. I experience very little immediate attraction to people, rather this grows gradually as a relationship develops and we build a connection. I can be quite romantic and value intimacy very highly once I become close to someone. However, for me, I find that romantic feelings are mutually, consciously cultivated; I never really â€œfallâ€ for people spontaneously. I like relationships to evolve slowly, and grow stronger over time. 


I find physical intimacy to be an important and valuable feature of relationships. That does not have to be sexual (I have had successful and happy relationships with asexual people). I find sexual activity to be a highly unique experience with every person; it is something I prefer to take slowly and gradually evolve. 


The gender of a partner is not an important component in degree of attraction towards them. In that sense, I am happy to identify as â€œbisexualâ€ or â€œpansexualâ€ or â€œqueerâ€, whichever is most conducive to good vibes or whatever.


I dislike uneven power dynamics.


When my relationships, career, finances, social setting etc are all in good shape, I would certainly consider having children with a suitable partner or partners. 
Ideologies and Identities
I am generally fairly anti-tribalist, and donâ€™t easily fully align with any groups. I tend to adopt far too many heretical views. Nonetheless, Iâ€™ll do my best to situate myself within the broad ideological contours of the contemporary moment.


I find politics interesting, and appreciate the importance of both policy and realpolitik. Overall, I broadly lie on the pluralist, progressive left, although this varies quite considerably, depending on contexts and issues. Economically, I sit somewhere between radical social democracy and market-oriented democratic socialism. Constitutionally and socially, I am very much a liberal, or perhaps more accurately I increasingly identify with classical civic republicanism. However, my views on particular policies and parties can be surprising; I instinctively avoid tribalism and political dogma, and try to borrow widely from a range of ideas. I am generally cautious of overarching grand narratives or overly simple ideological frameworks. I have some sympathy towards radical aims, but try to be pragmatic in my views on how to achieve them. I think democracy, liberty, equality, and constitutionalism are all good ideas, and many of the most interesting questions are about the best way to reconcile them.


In terms of political parties, I currently most closely align with the soft left of the Labour party in the U.K., though Iâ€™m rather hard to classify. Apparently (contrary to my claims in the previous section) I have some repressed masochistic inclinations because Iâ€™m still a Labour party member.


I am very much a feminist, mostly influenced by some ad hoc mixture of radical and intersectional ideas.


I am a culture wars irenicist, in that I think the culture war itself is bad and harmful. However, I am exasperated by both sides of these battles. Overall, my views are idiosyncratically radically progressive, but in some ways also quite culturally conservative.


I am very much a philosopher in every sense of the word (although please be very careful, because I am mildly allergic to metaphysics). Insofar as I have a philosophical project, it draws from the traditions of logical empiricism, subjective Bayesianism and Skyrmsian naturalism. And of course, I am very dedicated to physics (although our facebook relationship status is currently set to â€œit's complicatedâ€). I still lean towards some sort of hidden variables approach to quantum mechanics (in spite of my scientific anti-realism). I do see the appeal of an Everettian interpretation, but I have some deep, unresolved doubts.


Ethically, I have some sympathies with a utilitarian stance, but I may not be purely utilitarian. Decision theoretically, my views are not very settled, although I am not a naive causal decision theorist. Worryingly, I am not fully decided about whether that pushes me towards a sophisticated evidential decision theory, or some form of timeless decision theory. Either way, that means that my practical ethics looks a lot more deontological in practice than some utilitarians: I will cooperate in a twin prisonerâ€™s dilemma!


I am ontologically atheist, tropologically spiritual and theologically noncognitivist.


I broadly align with the fundamentals of the rationalist, post-rationalist and effective altruist approaches. They are fonts of absolutely incredible ideas. That being said, I harbour quite severe doubts about the epistemic and social health of the movements themselves. 


Lists of Things
(The purpose of these lists is to give a flavour. They're not intended to be exhaustive!)
Literature
Contemporary:
Margaret Atwood; Hilary Mantel; Kazuo Ishiguro; Jorge Luis Borges; Ian McEwan; Haruki Murakami; Umberto Eco; Graham Greene; John le CarrÃ©.
Classical:
Fyodor Dostoyevsky; George Eliot; Thomas Hardy; Jane Austen.
Multigenerational civilizational fantasy and science fiction epics:
The Hainish Cycle; the Foundation series; A Canticle for Leibowitz; the Dune Series; A Song of Ice and Fire.


For a long time, ADHD made me a very slow reader. It wasnâ€™t that I didnâ€™t enjoy reading, but that I found it overly-exciting, and my mind would keep wandering off, stimulated by the ideas. In recent years, medication, audio books, and better mastery of my symptoms have helped a great deal, and Iâ€™ve started consuming a lot more. But this means there are many gaps that I would like to fill.
Nonfiction
Godel, Escher, Bach; The Selfish Gene; Thinking Fast and Slow; Capital in the 21st Century; Seeing Like a State; Mathematical Games by Martin Gardner; Physics textbooks by David Griffiths, James Binney or James Blundel.
Music
Classical
Mozart; Beethoven; Bach; Sibelius; JanÃ¡Äek; Tchaikovsky; Bruckner; Mahler; Wagner (yes); Howells; Mendelssohn; Schubert; Prokofiev; Rachmaninov; Rimsky-Korsakov; Dvorak; Khachaturian; Byrd; Tallis; PÃ¤rt; Poulenc; Pergolesi.
Symphonic/Power/Folk Metal
Nightwish; Turisas; Sabaton; Blind Guardian; Helion Prime; Dragonforce.
Miscellanea
A lot of jazz and related genres: Dave Brubeck, Miles Davis. Sometimes I become temporarily fascinated by other particular genres of music: classical Hindustani ragas, maqam, klezmer, isochronic tones, etc.


I used to play clarinet, violin and trumpet, and I did choral singing for a while. To my eternal shame, I havenâ€™t kept up with these. But music remains extremely important to me, somewhere close to my soul.
Video Games
I play Age of Empires II online regularly with a group of friends (Elo ~ 1400 #humblebrag). Other games I enjoy or have enjoyed include:


Europa Universalis, Crusader Kings, Victoria; the Civilization Series; Cities Skylines; Rimworld; Factorio; Open TTD; Disco Elysium; Pentiment; the Baldurâ€™s Gate series; Planescape Torment; Monkey Island; Grim Fandango; Chrono Trigger.


I tend to go through long periods of not playing any games. But when my mental reserves run to zero, sometimes some part of my brain rebels, and I become fixated on a game for a little while, before I recover.
Films
I donâ€™t watch many. Some that I enjoy include: 


American Beauty; anything by Hayao Miyazaki/Studio Ghibli; Pan's Labyrinth; Schindler's List.
Broadcast media
I donâ€™t consume very much broadcast media.


Carl Sagan's Cosmos; documentaries by Adam Curtis; Bryan Magee's wonderful interviews; most things on BBC Radio 4.
Youtube Channels
3Blue1Brown; PBS Spacetime; Kurzgesagt; CGP Grey; Maiorianus; Voices of the Past.
Blogs
Azimuth; Astral Codex Ten; A Collection of Unmitigated Pedantry; Stumbling and Mumbling; Mainly Macro; Noapinion; Shtetl-Optimized; whatever Wolfram is doing; Chartbook; Age of Invention; Scientific Discovery.
Food
I am almost entirely vegan and strictly vegetarian. Beyond that, I am fairly flexible. Some of my favourite foods include:


* Chocolate.
A Perfect Day
In the golden light of the dawn, I head to the gymnasium, its tall, firm Corinthian columns silhouetted against the morning sun. I debate with the other great philosophers as we watch the naked male youths wrestle in the palaestra. Their lithe forms glisten with perspiration, as they dance in tandem, mind and body in exquisite harmony. With the day's exertion done, I wander back to my oikos, where I am hosting a symposium, with all the foremost intelligentsia of the polis. I ran a birthday â€œdooms & destiniesâ€ conversation on chathamroom.com (a web site I made) for my 31st birthday, in late November 2022. I invited the 15 people who know me best (apart from my family), including 2 ex-partners and 1 current partner, to contribute any thoughts or advice they had for me (without revealing which of the 15 said what). Here are most of the things they said (leaving out some that donâ€™t make sense without more context):
* You are easy for me to feel warmly toward, and to care about, and to expect care from, and to expect to have be able to care about other people. I think this is really great. It seems kinda rare among my friends, or among Berkeley people.
* You are an attentive and sincere and intelligent conversation partner, and talking to you is in a nice way like talking to myself, more than for most people. It's probably important that you are reasonable and I trust your judgment a lot. And also that I think you rarely misunderstand me. It feels like we can talk with a lot of precision.
* You don't work with imperfection well. It seems like you need to fix imperfections that somehow shouldn't bother youâ€¦ [On the other hand,] You don't pretend that things are perfect when they're not. You don't accept things are good when they don't seem so to you. You believe in concrete paths forward to better things that you, personally, could start on today
* You seem to want to trade or commensurate in an unusual way when it comes to human relationships. Like, "I don't want to do X when talking to people. But it seems like I should be able to do Y instead [in conversation or elsewhere in life] and still get Z??". I don't know if this possible, but it seems like it's not working for most Z
* You are kind. It seems like your kindness goes first to the rejected and ashamed. You are not a fair-weather friend.
   * +1. I also appreciate this about you.
   * Yes, I would never worry that Ben would not want to hang out with me/care for me because I 'became less cool' or was depressed or something, he feels very dependable and loyal.
*  you are good at making things! This is great.
   * Relatedly, you are good at imagining the world in ways that it is not, and thinking them through, and good to talk to re this.
* you have a kind of trust in your own ability to do things that I admire, and that I wish more people had. This is probably related to the person who said "you are good at making things!". In me it sits as a kind of self-trust, and I admire it and see it as a source of strength and grounding.
   * +1 because I think this actually rubbed off on me some when we were working on something together and it's been a net positive in other parts of my life.
   *   Yes I like this a lot about Ben. And in particular I think you do this in a way that doesn't make other people feel inferior/inadequate, you're being competent very much for yourself rather than performatively
   *   I also find it both adorable and inspirational how much you are excited and nerdy about making and solving and building things
* I think you tend to over-identify with things? With certain groups of people and identities but also with specific behaviors and struggles in a way that can be self-fulfillling
* You decline a lot of invitations, but ask that you still be invited to the next thing, because you are actually interested but something is going on. This only works for so long. Ive seen people stop inviting you despite the requests because it gets old. As a destiny, which you do actually show up, you are a lot of fun to be around.
   * my sense is that you get a lot out of being with other people (i.e. are not fundamentally a loner type person, at least in ways) but are often relatively alone because specific opportunities are bad in ways. But you then don't often cause social things yourself that would be good. My guess is that doing so is costly and not immediately worth it, but I wonder if it would lead to a better overall part of the landscape if you got an affordance for it.
* I think Ben is very broadly likable. I don't recall hearing of a person saying they have negative sentiment toward him in general, and people often seem to have positive sentiment.
   *   Yes, I think Ben is broadly regarded as a sweetheart and very nice to have around
* I appreciate how much integrity you have
* You're very generous with your time and efforts - I really appreciate times you've e.g. helped drive me to places, helped me solve technical problems, etc
* You have too many preferences and/or pay too much attention to small preferences; on the margin, I think you should prioritize 'being ok with a wider range of things; learning to ignore annoyances or appreciate different kinds of things' over 'changing things to suit your preferences'. I can try to think of examples if that's unclear as it is.
* You are a great teacher. I think this is a related to other destinies of groundedness about your competence, intrinsic interest in doing things, patience and gentleness and attentiveness with other people. You are very good at explaining things, sharing interest and excitement about them, not making the recipient feel dumb for not knowing stuff already, making it feel easy to ask questions, providing positive reinforcement for sharing confusion and questions, making people feel like a good student. It seems like you also enjoy teaching. I think this is an asset in life in general even if you don't make it an explicit part of your career, but I think you could consider trying to take advantage of this even more.
* You score the highest of almost anyone I know on some kind of social attentiveness to imposition/inconvenience/asking things of people. This makes you very considerate and sweet, but I think it can also cause unnecessary suffering for you and others. I do think the underlying trait is definitely an asset, but you can probably shape it into something that involves less negative affectâ€¦ almost all of your apologizing is for things where there isn't anything in particular I would have wanted you to do differently). I don't think this is hugely important - I see this overall thing as an endearing trait that's part of what makes you such a sweetheart, but seems like it causes you a bit more pain than is necessary.


Appendix C: Why I temporarily donâ€™t do drugs
I want life insurance, in order to sign up for cryonics. I refused to lie on the application, despite my insurance agentâ€™s preference that I do so. I learned that if youâ€™ve done any illegal drugs other than marijuana in the last five years, and are stupid/stubborn enough to tell them so on the application, they just will not insure you no matter what. So Iâ€™m now about three years through a five-year drug-free period.
Iâ€™ve written a bit about my approach to honesty, which results in my unwillingness to lie to the insurance company.

Appendix: Detailed Explanations

I practice hierarchical polyamory.
Many sources such as More Than Two will tell you this is a red flag, but this is incorrect. Hierarchical relationships set an absolute minimum amount of communication about the health and status of the relationship.

I like the idea of â€˜feralâ€™-ish fights for control, but it may turn out I hate that if I lose.

Leaning into the â€œthereâ€™s no such thing as oversharing,â€ here are some reflections on past relationships:


Why did some of my last relationships not work out? 
* We didnâ€™t want the same lifestyle (he wanted #vanlife)
* We didnâ€™t want to live in the same place (I wanted to be in California)
* Our politics (and underlying values) were too different 
* We had different approaches to relationships â€“ they felt like it should just work or not work, and I wanted to be on an ongoing journey together to make it work
* We had different communication styles and preferences â€“ I would rather talk and hear about whatâ€™s not working so we can solve it together and understand each other better, but they found that to be stressful


What might be things my exes say about me? 


Some good stuff: 
* Iâ€™m very caring and thoughtful and generous
* I laugh a lot and love to have fun and I feel excitement and awe at small and big things alike
* I bring up the hard things and am willing to do the work, whether itâ€™s together or work I need to do on my end
* I have great friends!! 
* I am great at logistics and making things happen


Some bad stuff: 
* I have a full life and time with friends is a priority (for an ex who wanted to spend most nights together, this was tough)
* Itâ€™s hard for me to feel deeply connected to people who donâ€™t care about and prioritize making the world better; people Iâ€™ve dated who were, say, a data scientist at an e-commerce company, found this to be really dogmatic. 
* Iâ€™m not hesitant to bring up things that arenâ€™t working for me; especially when Iâ€™ve dated people who donâ€™t feel as comfortable doing this, what I have brought up weighed on them or it felt like to them that I couldnâ€™t be happy in the relationship.
* Iâ€™m better at giving than receiving - in my best relationships weâ€™ve both given a lot and enjoyed that, but Iâ€™ve also had relationships where theyâ€™ve felt like itâ€™s a burden. One ex said â€œcanâ€™t you just do fewer things for me, so I donâ€™t feel like I have to do things for you?â€ BUT I also am working on being better at asking for help and receiving it. 


Looking for someone who read all of this and is curious, felt that some of this resonated with them, has questionsâ€¦ reach out! Looking forward to connecting with you.


Inspired by other friendsâ€™ profilesâ€¦ thank you. Also, if you want to date a different Bay Area pickleball fanatic who cares about making the world a better place, check out Taren's date-me page as well! Sheâ€™s a great friend and an inspiring changemaker, and I want her to find her person too!

Goals

Life Story (the first date drivel)

2. I went to University of St Andrews in Scotland. I studied economics, was a rower (and coach), and generally had a great time being slightly immature but also trying to be sophisticated.
3. I came back to Chicago after graduating, and sold my soul to a bank. I dove in way too deep and became way too much of a recluse while COVID raged. 
4. I needed a change and used my bargaining power to find myself a role out in San Francisco. I moved out at the end of 2021 and have been trying to find myself again.
I have two great parents (both work in finance too, I know we suck), an older brother who is outshining me by having a fiance + a dog + a house in Chicago, and always grew up with Golden Retrievers and Corgis (cool ones).
My Flaunts

My Faults

What my friends say: borshch
It is hard to have an objective evaluation of a human being, so I found borshch to be the closest proxy for estimating quality of me as future wife.
Borshch is a Ukrainian soup that takes ~2-3 hours to make and is often cooked as a test for marriage readiness. A wife (yes wife, not a man bc men do not cook!!!) is only as good as her borshch (ah, what a great way to reduce human complexity:).
My friend said, â€œthe caliber of a person is determined not by any single borscht they cooked, but that they keep cooking borscht. It is the borscht of the soul that makes the borscht of the stomach.â€
I fed my friends with borshch and asked some follow-up qs.
